Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: High Performance Structural Composites with Cellulosic Nanoparticles
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project is to create cost-effective, sustainable, high performance nanocomposites for automotive and other industries. The automotive industry is currently using 2.7 billion pounds per year of sustainable polymeric composites with an estimated US market of $23 billion by 2017. The initial target is to replace heavy glass reinforcement in polymeric composites with cellulosic nanocrystals (CNCs) for car parts, providing lighter weight vehicles with increased fuel efficiency. CNCs are an abundant and renewable natural resource, with the feedstock provided by wood or waste from wood processing to make pulp, paper, and lumber. On-going research on the production of CNCs from various wood sources have resulted in significant reductions in cost (with more coming), making CNCs an increasingly attractive functional natural filler. Developing CNCs that can be scaled up to make larger parts at a commercially attractive price is a key objective in this research. Successful implementation of CNCs into composites could not only lighten vehicles and reduce environmental impact, but also transform a waste stream into high-value materials.

This effort will address three previously encountered challenges with incorporating CNCs into polymeric thermoplastic composites, namely: (1) particle dispersion, (2) interfacial bonding, and (3) commercially viable processing methods for large-scale manufacturing for automotive and other industries. CNCs have more than twice the tensile strength of aramid fibers and a greater tensile strength and lower density than carbon fibers. Novel interfacial chemistries and processing paths will have to be developed in order to achieve proper interfacial bonding between CNCs and the polymer matrices, as well as dispersion of the CNC particles to allow the polymeric composite to realize the superior mechanical properties that CNCs can provide. The scalability and cost of the chemistries and processing will also be a primary consideration in this investigation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Small Business Innovation Research Phase I Project allowed for the initial research and development of Essentium Materials’ high-strength thermoplastic composites reinforced with cellulosic nanoparticles as a replacement for heavier glass-reinforced composite materials for structural automotive components. The Corporate Average Fuel Economy (CAFE) regulations are pushing for significant increases in fuel economy for vehicles, which has led OEMs to look for innovative ways to shed vehicle weight in order to improve fuel economy. It has been shown that for every 10% in weight savings, vehicle fuel consumption is reduced by 7%. During the SBIR Phase I period, the company showed that thermoplastic composites reinforced with cellulosic nanoparticles could meet the tensile strength values of glass-reinforced composites at much higher loadings, thereby saving part weight.

The objective of the Phase I project was to develop a CNC-reinforced thermoplastic composite that could meet the tensile properties of a glass fiber automotive material specification, provided by an automotive OEM partner. The research objectives were to investigate dispersion, interfacial effects, and polymer processing techniques that were commercially scalable. Through the Phase I and IB efforts, Essentium Materials developed a composite with 5 wt% nanocellulose that meets the tensile strength requirement for a 20 wt% short glass fiber PP composite with a novel approach that does not require a separate treatment process for the CNCs. This technology could result in a weight savings between 7-13% or more compared to the incumbent short glass fiber composites, and has resulted in one provisional patent application.

Nanocellulose-based composites are replete with social, educational, and scientific benefits. The target application is to replace heavy glass reinforcement in polymeric composites with CNCs for car parts, providing lighter weight vehicles with increased fuel efficiency. This nets strong environmental benefits. On-going research on the production of CNCs from various wood sources have resulted in significant reductions in cost (with more coming), making CNCs an increasingly attractive functional natural filler, the processing of which, will provide jobs in both manufacturing and the high-tech sector. Successful implementation of CNCs into composites could not only lighten vehicles and reduce environmental impact, but also transform a waste stream into high-value materials helping meet current societal needs while sustainably creating new, less harmful materials for future generations. 

 


Last Modified: 10/15/2015
Modified by: Elisa Teipel
